{"title":"Section 2, Page 33","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"33
t,y the magic of eloquence, and the prestige of
" The immortal names,
That were not born to die."
Once having penetrated into the interior of our neighbor-
rfig state, our railroad must eventually find an outlet on the
pacific. It was a happy idea of yours, Mr. President, that
the first bar of irln which would be laid upon the track at
Algiers, would be followed up continuously by others, which
would terminate only on the shores of the Pacific ocean.—
The march of empire and of public improvement, bend their
course alike towards the setting sun. And in a few years,
the same genius which has suspended bridges over the falls
of Niagara, and communicated with a vocabulary snatched
from the lightning, will send its long and pompous train over
the iron highway, that shall terminate only on the shores of
the Pacific. I believe, gentlemen, as I believe in your existence and in mine, that 'it is in our power, with the cooperation of Texas, to give shape and direction to this great
enterprise. We may advance with it so far, that its completion to California will be secured—not by Louisiana, not by
Texas—but by the urgent demands and the united will of the
people of the entire Union. We shall then occupy a central
point, in the great commercial highway of the world. The
commerce of the East Indies—the commerce which has been
cherished by nations through all time—will flow through our
borders, and impart more than eastern wealth and splendor
tu this great emporium of the valley of the Mississippi. The
wealthy productions and the gorgeous fabrics of the Indies,
—which contributed thousands of years ago to the magnificence and grandeur of Babylon, and Nincvah, and Palmyra,
and Carthage—will be daily landed upon our wharves and
received by our princely merchants. Throngs of citizens
from iar distant shores, will daily crowd our streets, bringing
with them the language, the customs, the wealth, of those
enchanted regions, watered by streams
" Whose foam is amber and whose sands are gold."
